21.name: FTP - File Transfer Protocol
21.description: File Transfer Protocol often misconfigured with anonymous access or weak credentials in CTF challenges.

22.name: SSH - Secure Shell
22.description: Secure Shell service, often targeted for brute force attacks or exploiting weak keys in CTFs.

23.name: Telnet
23.description: Unencrypted remote access protocol, commonly found in IoT and legacy system CTF challenges.

25.name: SMTP - Simple Mail Transfer Protocol
25.description: Email service often vulnerable to user enumeration and relay attacks in CTF scenarios.

53.name: DNS - Domain Name System
53.description: DNS service vulnerable to zone transfers and cache poisoning in CTF challenges.

80.name: HTTP - HyperText Transfer Protocol
80.description: Standard web service port, primary target for web application vulnerabilities in CTFs.

110.name: POP3 - Post Office Protocol v3
110.description: Email retrieval protocol, often vulnerable to brute force and plaintext auth in CTFs.

111.name: RPCbind
111.description: RPC service mapper, reveals available RPC services and often leads to NFS enumeration.

135.name: MS-RPC - Microsoft RPC
135.description: Microsoft RPC endpoint mapper, critical for Windows enumeration and SMB attacks.

139.name: NetBIOS-SSN
139.description: NetBIOS Session Service, used for SMB file sharing and often vulnerable to null sessions.

143.name: IMAP - Internet Message Access Protocol
143.description: Email access protocol allowing mailbox manipulation, often misconfigured in CTFs.

161.name: SNMP - Simple Network Management Protocol
161.description: Network management protocol often using default community strings, goldmine for enumeration.

389.name: LDAP - Lightweight Directory Access Protocol
389.description: Directory service protocol, often allows anonymous binds revealing user/group information.

443.name: HTTPS - HTTP over SSL/TLS
443.description: Encrypted web service, target for certificate issues and web vulnerabilities.

445.name: SMB - Server Message Block
445.description: Modern SMB/CIFS port, primary target for file share enumeration and exploitation.

512.name: rexec
512.description: Remote execution service, legacy unencrypted protocol for command execution.

513.name: rlogin
513.description: Remote login service, legacy protocol often with trust relationships.

514.name: rsh/syslog
514.description: Remote shell or syslog service, often exposes sensitive logs or allows command execution.

515.name: LPD - Line Printer Daemon
515.description: Print server daemon, often allows arbitrary file access through print jobs.

548.name: AFP - Apple Filing Protocol
548.description: Apple file sharing protocol, often misconfigured with guest access.

1433.name: MSSQL - Microsoft SQL Server
1433.description: Microsoft SQL Server, critical in Windows CTF/HTB environments for xp_cmdshell execution, linked server attacks, and domain escalation.

1521.name: Oracle - Database TNS Listener
1521.description: Oracle TNS Listener, enterprise database often vulnerable to TNS poisoning, default credentials, and complex privilege escalation in advanced CTFs.

3306.name: MySQL - Database Server
3306.description: MySQL database server, ubiquitous in CTF web challenges with SQL injection, UDF exploitation, and file system access vulnerabilities.

3389.name: RDP - Remote Desktop Protocol
3389.description: Remote Desktop Protocol, critical Windows service often vulnerable to BlueKeep, credential attacks, and lateral movement in CTF scenarios.

5432.name: PostgreSQL - Database Server
5432.description: PostgreSQL database, common in modern CTF challenges with SQL injection, privilege escalation through extensions, and command execution capabilities.

5900.name: VNC - Virtual Network Computing
5900.description: VNC remote desktop service, often weakly protected with simple passwords or authentication bypass vulnerabilities in CTF challenges.

5985.name: WinRM - Windows Remote Management (HTTP)
5985.description: Windows Remote Management over HTTP, critical for PowerShell remoting and lateral movement in Windows domain CTF environments.

5986.name: WinRM - Windows Remote Management (HTTPS)
5986.description: Encrypted Windows Remote Management, used for secure PowerShell remoting and often indicates enterprise Windows environments in CTFs.

6379.name: Redis - In-Memory Data Structure Store
6379.description: Redis key-value store, frequently misconfigured without authentication leading to data exposure, SSH key injection, and RCE in CTF challenges.

27017.name: MongoDB - NoSQL Database
27017.description: MongoDB NoSQL database, often exposed without authentication allowing database dumping and JavaScript injection in CTF scenarios.

banners: It looks like you are trying to access MongoDB

993.name: IMAPS - Secure IMAP
993.description: Secure IMAP email service over SSL/TLS, common target for credential brute-forcing and mail data extraction in CTF challenges involving mail servers.

995.name: POP3S - Secure POP3
995.description: Secure POP3 email retrieval over SSL/TLS, often misconfigured with weak passwords allowing email harvesting in CTF mail server challenges.

8761.name: Eureka Server - Spring Cloud Discovery
8761.description: Spring Cloud Eureka service discovery server, critical for microservices enumeration and often exposes internal service URLs and actuator endpoints in CTF cloud challenges.

/eureka/apps.reason: Lists all registered microservices and their endpoints

/actuator.reason: Spring Boot actuator endpoints often expose sensitive info

3000.name: Gitea/Node.js Development Server
3000.description: Common port for Gitea git service, Node.js development servers, and various web applications. Prime target for git repository exposure and development environment misconfigurations in CTF challenges.

/api/v1/repos/search.reason: Gitea API endpoint lists public repositories

/.git/config.reason: Exposed git repository in development servers

8080.name: HTTP Proxy/Application Server
8080.description: Alternative HTTP port commonly used by Jenkins, Tomcat, JBoss, and proxy servers. Critical target for admin panel access, Java deserialization, and proxy abuse in CTF enterprise challenges.

/manager/html.reason: Tomcat manager often has default credentials

8000.name: HTTP Alternative/Development Server
8000.description: Alternative HTTP port used by Python development servers, Django, Git web interfaces, and various applications. Common in CTF challenges with development environment exposures.

5000.name: Flask Development Server
5000.description: Flask development server default port, also used by Docker Registry and various Python applications. Often misconfigured with debug mode enabled allowing RCE in CTF web challenges.

/console.reason: Werkzeug debug console allows Python code execution

/v2/_catalog.reason: Docker Registry API lists all images

8443.name: HTTPS Alternative
8443.description: Alternative HTTPS port used by various web services, admin panels, and applications. Common in CTF challenges for SSL/TLS misconfigurations and certificate vulnerabilities.

/admin.reason: Admin panel often on alternative HTTPS ports

10000.name: Webmin - System Administration
10000.description: Webmin web-based system administration interface, frequently vulnerable to authenticated RCE and privilege escalation in CTF Linux challenges.

/session_login.cgi.reason: Webmin login page, check for default creds

/file/show.cgi.reason: File manager often allows arbitrary file read

9200.name: Elasticsearch - Search and Analytics
9200.description: Elasticsearch REST API, often exposed without authentication leading to data leaks and server compromise through script execution in CTF data storage challenges.

/_cat/indices?v.reason: Lists all indices with document counts

/_search.reason: Search endpoint can dump all data

/_cluster/settings.reason: Cluster settings may reveal sensitive config
